questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented to medicine OPD with mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation as shown in the ECG below. Later he was put on therapy for ventricular tachycardia. While on treatment he develops a regular pulse of 76 beats/min. Which of the following drug has caused the normalization of rhythm?
questions.solution:
Digitalis is used to control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation.

  • Mechanism of Action:

It increases the refractoriness of AV node and decreases the conduction through AV node.

In Atrial Fibrillation, atrium beats at very high rate (500 beats/minute), and at such high rates the contractions become ineffective.

  • Thus, aim of treatment in atrial fibrillation is to maintain ventricular rate at low levels.
  • Digitalis does so by its vagomimetic effect that decreases AV conduction.
  • Vagomimetic effect is also responsible for bradycardia due to digitalis therapy.
  • In atrial flutter, it is difficult to control the ventricular rate.

Digitalis converts atrial flutter to AF, in which ventricular rate can be controlled easily.

Drug treatment for different Arrhythmias


Topic: Ventricular tachycardia

questions.text: A 45-year-old male brought to Emergency Department with complaints of chest pain while exertion and later diagnosed of having stable angina. Which of the following preparations of Nitroglycerin should be prescribed to him as it has the most rapid onset of action?
questions.solution:
Nitroglycerin

Peak concentrations of GTN are found in plasma within 4 min of sublingual administration; the drug has a t1/2 of 1-3 min.

The onset of action of GTN may be even more rapid if delivered as a sublingual spray rather than as a sublingual tablet.

Sublingual route of administration has a very rapid onset of action (1 min). Onset of action is more rapid when administered as spray when compared to tablet.

Sublingual route is used for termination of attacks.


Oral extended-release capsule and transdermal patches are used for prophylaxis. The onset of action is approximately ≥60 min.

questions.text: By which amongst the following routes, amyl nitrite is administered for termination of an Anginal attack?
questions.solution:
Amyl nitrite is administered via inhalation for acute relief in angina and cyanide poisoning.

Amyl nitrite is a highly volatile liquid. It is available in fragile glass ampules packaged in a protective cloth covering.

Its action has a very rapid onset like that of sublingual administration, but unpleasant odour, and a very short duration of action (3-5 min) has made its use obsolete in angina.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female brought to Emergency Department with complaints of episodic chest pain while at rest and it has no relation with exertion and later on diagnosed of having variant angina. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug should be prescribed to her as it shows mortality benefit in variant (Prinzmetal) angina?
questions.solution:
Ca² channel blockers provide benefit in patients with variant angina through their effect on coronary vasodilation.

Ca² channel blockers are effective in about 90% of patients with variant angina and are considered as first-line agents.

They are the only agents that have been shown to provide mortality benefit in variant angina.

Option A: Nitrates can be effective in abolishing episodes of variant angina but do not offer mortality benefit.

Option B: Beta-blockers are to be avoided in variant angina as they can augment coronary vasoconstriction through unopposed alpha action. They do not offer mortality benefit.

Topic: Calcium channel blockers in Prinzmetal angina

questions.text: Which of the following drug is absolutely contraindicated in patients with the presence of cardiac failure (CHF)?
questions.solution:
Mannitol is contraindicated in cardiac failure patients.

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It acts by increasing the osmolality of extracellular fluid and resulting in extraction of water from intracellular compartments.

The net effect is increase in extracellular fluid volume that can cause volume overload and frank pulmonary edema in cardiac failure patients.

Mannitol is contraindicated in renal insufficiency, acute tubular necrosis, anuria, pulmonary edema; acute left ventricular failure, CHF and cerebral haemorrhage.

[Very important question]

questions.text: Which amongst the following statement regarding lignocaine is least correct with respect to its either pharmacokinetic or pharmacodynamic property?
questions.solution:
Lignocaine decreased the incidence of arrhythmias in patients with suspected MI but increased mortality probably by precipitating heart block or congestive heart failure.

Therefore, routine use for prophylaxis in MI patients is not recommended but used only when indicated.

Gastrointestinal absorption of lignocaine is good but bioavailability is very less due to high first-pass hepatic metabolism. Therefore, it is not used through the oral route.

Lignocaine has a high volume of distribution. The loading dose is required to achieve rapid action.

In heart failure, both volumes of distribution and clearance is reduced. Both loading dose and maintenance dose has to be reduced.

questions.text: An elderly male patient with history of heart failure developed atrial fibrillation. His ECG findings as shown in the below image confirmed atrial fibrillation. He was brought to emergency department and immediately stabilised on digoxin. By which of the following mechanism, digoxin helps to control patient's arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
Digoxin increases vagal tone through central effect.

Increased vagal tone improves ventricular rate control in atrial fibrillation.

Effect of increased vagal tone:

Increased AV nodal refractoriness due to blockade of Ca2+ channels

Hyperpolarisation and shortening of atrial action potentials due to activation of Ach mediated K+ channels in atrium.

questions.text: Which of the following group of drugs decreases both plasma renin activity and plasma renin concentration?
questions.solution:
Beta blockers decrease both plasma renin activity and plasma renin concentration by decreasing sympathetic flow.

Renin is secreted from JG cells, either due to stimulation by β1 receptor

activation or due to decreased fluid delivery to macula densa.

Therefore, the drugs that inhibit activation of β1 receptors (directly by β-blockers) will result in decrease in plasma renin activity.

Antihypertensive drugs will increase plasma renin activity due to compensatory mechanisms (diuretics, ACEI and ARBs) decrease the fluid volume resulting in reduction of fluid delivery to macula densa and vasodilators increase sympathetic activity and therefore result in activation of β1 receptors).


Topic: Beta blockers ( Renin Angiotensin aldosterone system)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male came to medicine OPD with long standing history of uncontrolled hypertension and now diagnosed of having bilateral renal artery stenosis. Which of the following anti-hypertensive drug is the best choice for an elderly hypertensive patient having history of bilateral renal artery stenosis?
questions.solution:
Thiazides and beta blockers should be avoided in diabetes mellitus whereas ACE inhibitors should not be given to a patient with bilateral renal artery stenosis.

Therefore, CCBs like verapamil are best agents to manage hypertension in such a patient.

Advantages of CCBs are:

  1. Do not compromise haemodynamics: no impairment of physical work capacity.
  2. No sedation or other CNS effects
  3. Not contraindicated in asthma, angina (especially variant) and PVD patients
  4. Are particularly effective in elderly patients, black races and low renin hypertensives.
  5. 5. Do not affect male sexual function.
  6. No deleterious effect on plasma lipid profile, uric acid level and electrolyte balance.
  7. Shown to have no/minimal effect on quality of life.
  8. No adverse foetal effects; can be used during pregnancy

The long-acting DHPs are next to ACE inhibitors in reducing albuminuria and slowing disease progression in hypertensive/diabetic nephropathy.

Topic: Verapamil( Antihypertensive).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 531-580

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presented to emergency department in unconscious state with a history of head trauma due to road traffic accident. In hospital, the patient developed Seizures. On further investigation CT scan of head revealed widespread cerebral edema (as shown in the image below). Which of the following diuretic is the drug of choice for cerebral edema in this patient?
questions.solution:
Mannitol

Mannitol is a nonelectrolyte of low molecular weight.

It is minimally metabolized in the body; freely filtered at the glomerulus and undergoes limited reabsorption: therefore, excellently suited to be used as an osmotic diuretic.

Uses

Mannitol is never used for the treatment of chronic edema or as a natriuretic.

Its indications are:

  1. Increased intracranial or intraocular tension (acute congestive glaucoma, head injury, stroke): by osmotic action it encourages movement of water from brain parenchyma, CSF and aqueous humour.
  2. To maintain glomerular filtration rate and urine flow in impending acute renal failure, e.g. in shock, severe trauma, cardiac surgery, haemolytic reactions.
  3. To counteract low osmolality of plasma and Extracellular Fluid due to rapid haemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis (dialysis disequilibrium).

[Previous year topic]

Topic: Mannitol in cerebral edema.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 637

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient named Raman has history of chronic asthma and he is ongoing treatment with theophylline. Later he developed upper respiratory tract infection with mild pneumonitis. Which of the following is the most suitable option to safely treat his upper respiratory tract infection without compromising treatment of asthma?
questions.solution:
Interactions

  1. Agents which enhance theophylline metabolism primarily by inducing CYP1A2 lower its plasma level: dose has to be increased by the factor given in parenthesis. Smoking (1.6), phenytoin (1.5), rifampicin (1.5), phenobarbitone (1.2), charcoal broiled meat meal (1.3).
  2. Drugs which inhibit theophylline metabolism and increase its plasma level are-erythromycin, ciprofloxacin, cimetidine, oral contraceptives, allopurinol; dose should be reduced to 2/3.
  • Mnemonic

Enzyme inhibitors [ Virat Kohli Can't Call Every Indians]

Valproate

Ketoconazole

Cimetidine

Ciprofloxacin/Clarithromycin

Erythromycin

INH

  1. Theophylline enhances the effects of- furosemide, sympathomimetics, digitalis, oral anticoagulants, hypoglycaemics.
  2. Theophylline decreases the effects of- phenytoin, lithium.

Azithromycin has been found not to affect hepatic CYP3A4 enzyme. Interaction with theophylline, carbamazepine, warfarin, terfenadine and cisapride is not likely, but caution may be exercised.

Topic: Theophylline drug interaction

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy brought to paediatric ICU with complaints of acute breathlessness with wheezing. He was later diagnosed of having sudden attack of bronchial asthma and given aminophylline infusion. Which of the following is the most accurate dose of aminophylline to be given as slow intravenous infusion in children for bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Aminophylline (Theophylline-ethylenediamine; 85% theophylline) water soluble, can be injected intravenous but not intramuscular or subcutaneous-highly irritating.

250-500 mg oral or slow intravenous injection; children 7.5 mg/kg i.v.;

Intravenous aminophylline, an ethylene diamine ester of theophylline that is water soluble, has been used for many years in the treatment of acute severe asthma.

The recommended dose is 6 mg/kg given intravenously over 20-30 min, followed by a maintenance dose of 0.5 mg/kg per hour.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient brought to pulmonary department with chronic asthma. After consultation with pulmonologist she was prescribed a combination medicine via inhalation route. After some days of taking the medicine she presented to OTORHINOLOGY department with oral thrush/canidiasis. Which of the following is the most suitable drug for its treatment?
questions.solution:
Clotrimazole

It is the most commonly used topical imidazole effective in the treatment of tinea infections like

  • Oral/cutaneous/vaginal candidiasis.

For oropharyngeal candidiasis 10 mg troche of clotrimazole is allowed to dissolve in the mouth 3-4 times a day, or the lotion/gel is applied/swirled in the mouth for as long as possible.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child brought to paediatric OPD with complaints of exercise induced asthma. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug for regular prophylactic therapy for this child for exercise induced asthma?
questions.solution:
Sodium cromoglycate (Cromolyn sod.)

It is a synthetic chromone derivative which inhibits degranulation of mast cells.

Release of mediators of asthma like histamine, LTs, PAF, interleukins, etc. is restricted.

Bronchospasm induced by allergens, irritants, cold air and exercise may be attenuated.

Uses

  1. Bronchial asthma
  2. Allergic rhinitis
  3. Allergic conjunctivitis

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the most accurate statement(s) about use of inhaled glucocorticoids in patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)?
questions.solution:
Inhaled Glucocorticoids in COPD:

The airway inflammation in COPD is not very responsive to corticosteroids.

As such, only high dose Inhaled Corticosteroids are beneficial in advanced COPD with frequent exacerbations.

They should not be used in early/mild cases. There is no proof that they retard the progression of COPD.

questions.text: A 41-year-old female patient named Malti has a history of chronic asthma since long and she went to her physician for treatment. Her physician has characterised her asthma into "mild persistent asthma with occasional exacerbation" and suggested an inhaled medication. Which of the following β2 agonist bronchodilators is given by inhalation, and is suitable for both terminating asthma attacks as well as for twice daily prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Formoterol is a long-acting β2-selective receptor agonist.

Significant bronchodilation, which may persist for up to 12 h, occurs within minutes of inhalation of a therapeutic dose.

It is highly lipophilic and has high affinity for β2 receptors.

Its major advantage over many other β2-selective agonists is this prolonged duration of action, which may be particularly advantageous in settings such as nocturnal asthma.

It is FDA-approved for treatment of asthma and bronchospasm, prophylaxis of exercise-induced bronchospasm, and COPD.

It can be used concomitantly with short-acting β2 agonists, glucocorticoids (inhaled or systemic), and theophylline.

[Moderate]

[Clinical question]

questions.text: A young girl of 27 years of age stable on Antidepressant therapy presented to emergency with palpitations, altered sensorium and hypotension. On investigations there is wide QRS interval and right axis deviation in ECG as shown in below image. Which amongst the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The clinical features and ECG findings typically suggest a diagnosis of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning.
  • Antidote for TCA poisoning is sodium bicarbonate.
  • Hemodialysis is not effective is TCA poisoning

Acute poisoning

Poisoning with TCAs is frequent; usually self-attempted for suicide, and may endanger life.

Manifestations are:

Excitement, delirium and other anticholinergic symptoms as seen in atropine poisoning, followed by muscle spasms, convulsions and coma.

Respiration is depressed, body temperature may fall, BP is low, tachycardia is prominent.

ECG changes and ventricular arrhythmias are common.

Treatment is primarily supportive with gastric lavage, respiratory assistance, fluid infusion, maintenance of BP and body temperature.

Acidosis must be corrected by bicarbonate infusion.

Diazepam may be injected intravenous to control convulsions and delirium.

Most important is the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/ lidocaine may be used.

[Difficult]

[Clinical question]

Topic:TCA toxicity.

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the most appropriate muscle relaxant of choice in a patient with elevated SGOT, SGPT and serum creatinine of 7.5 mg/dl with creatinine clearance of <45ml/min:
questions.solution:
Atracurium is eliminated by Hoffman's elimination.

It means it neither requires liver for metabolism, nor kidney for excretion. Its molecules spontaneously rearrange to make it inactive.

Thus it is safest muscle relaxant in a patient with liver and kidney disease.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male patient came to medicine department with complaints of forgetfulness, difficulty in concentration & thinking, confusion and inability to recognise common things. Brain imaging studies confirms the diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease (Image of CT head below). Which of the following is a relatively cerebroselective anticholinesterase found to afford symptomatic improvement in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Donepezil

This cerebroselective and reversible anti-AChE produces measurable improvement in several cognitive as well as non-cognitive functions

The benefit is ascribed to elevation of Acetylcholine levels in the cortex, especially in the surviving neurones that project from basal forebrain to cerebral cortex and hippocampus.

Therapeutic doses produce only weak peripheral AChE inhibition: cholinergic side effects are mild.

Because of long t½ (~70 hr), donepezil is administered once daily at bed time; a distinct advantage over rivastigmine and galantamine which need twice daily dosing.

Moreover, it can be used even in relatively severe case of Alzheimer's disease (AD).

Donepezil is generally well tolerated and is not hepatotoxic.

[Moderate]

[Clinical question]

Topic:cerebroselective anticholinesterase.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number.518-519

questions.text: A 67-year-old male came to medicine department with slow gait, tremors, impaired memory and sluggishness in activity. He was later diagnosed of having Parkinson disease. Which of the following Antiparkinsonian drug if given long term known to cause cardiac valvular fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Ergot derivatives act on several different neurotransmitter systems, including DA, 5HT, and adrenergic receptors.

Bromocriptine and pergolide have been used for the treatment of Parkinson disease

However, their use is associated with risk for serious cardiac complications, specifically, the promotion of valvular heart disease due to 5HT2B serotonin receptor Stimulation.

Ergot derivatives are commonly reported to cause unpleasant side effects, including nausea, dizziness, and hallucinations.

Pergolide was removed from the U.S. market as therapy for Parkinson disease after it was associated with an increased risk for valvular heart disease.

[Moderate]

[Very important question]

Topic: pergolide

questions.text: A 56-year-old male unconscious patient with history of consuming unknown medicines was brought to emergency department suspected of having benzodiazepine poisoning. Flumazenil was repeatedly administered and the cumulative dose was around 5 mg over 10 minutes. The patient did not respond. What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
A lack of response at 5 mg cumulative flumazenil dose strongly suggests against benzodiazepine poisoning.

Series of small injections >>> single bolus injections for flumazenil injections

A total of 1 mg over 1-3 minutes is enough for reversing therapeutic doses of benzodiazepines. If the response does not occur at 5 mg, other poisoning is suspected.

questions.solution:
The patient is having a hypersensitivity reaction to phenytoin that warrants discontinuation of phenytoin.

ADRs of Phenytoin

  • Mnemonic

H - Hirsutism, Hypertrophy of gums

O - Osteomalacia

T - Teratogenicity [Fetal Hydantoin syndrome]

K - ↓ Vitamin K levels

A - Ataxias, vertigo [cerebellar symptoms] [only at high dose]

Option A & C: Clonazepam and ethosuximide are primarily used in absence seizures and are not indicated for Generalized Tonic Clonic Seizures (GTCS).

Sodium valproate is one of the first-line agents Indicated for GTCS. Shifting to sodium valproate is the most appropriate course of action in this patient.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient with psychosis epilepsy was prescribed typical anti-psychotics by his psychiatrist. Later he developed extrapyramidal side effects of using those medications and he was told to discontinue medicines. Which of the following antipsychotics should be administered considering it has the least risk of causing extrapyramidal side effects?
questions.solution:
Clozapine and Quietiapine have shown to have the least extrapyramidal side effects amongst the atypical antipsychotics.

Compared with the typical antipsychotics, the atypical antipsychotics

  • Lower propensity to induce Extra pyramidal symptoms and tardive dyskinesia
  • Have a broader spectrum of efficacy.

The affinity of clozapine for D2 receptors is below the threshold that is predictive of Extra pyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia.
